Martin Heidegger: The Limiting Character of the Scientific Method

Jack Simmons

Abstract

In the hands of Edmund Husserl and Martin Heidegger, phenomenology became a way of reflecting upon the rigor of philosophy and science. While Husserl aimed at adding rigor to philosophical investigation, Heidegger, more profoundly, reveals the inherent weaknesses of the sciences, such as mathematics, physics and biology, in “obtaining and securing the primary way of access to what are supposedly the objects of this science.” Heidegger claims that the phenomenological method reveals the a priori conditions necessary for the sciences mentioned above, and the inherent weaknesses and blind spots of those disciplines. In this chapter, I propose to explain Heidegger’s criticism of scientific reasoning along with his call for a more profound approach to thinking that references both medieval and pre-Socratic world-views.

Introduction

In the hands of Edmund Husserl and Martin Heidegger, phenomenology became a way of reflecting upon the rigor of philosophy and science. While Husserl aimed at adding rigor to philosophical investigation, Heidegger attacked scientific thinking as having fallen under the sway of technology.

Heidegger points to Plato as the end of Greek thought and the beginning of a Western rationality that would give in to technological thinking, and I begin this chapter by identifying a brief passage in the Republic that demonstrates the shift towards technological mode of thinking. Here Plato compares the nature of a person to the nature of a tool.

Heidegger is also concerned with the extent to which modern science focuses on efficient causes (cause and effect), to the general exclusion of Aristotle’s formal cause, material cause and final cause. While efficient causes can provide material explanations for events, they cannot provide events with purpose of meaning. As a result, Heidegger contends that modern science results in nihilism.

Finally, I explain what technological thinking entails and what we might understand to be alternatives to technological modes of thinking. This is challenging because the metaphysics of modernity distorts alternative modes of thinking, and because Heidegger’s reference to pre-Socratic thinkers deploys what might be considered an intentionally obtuse vocabulary. But Heidegger’s early work on Duns Scotus offers a simpler entre into a world that is philosophically and scientifically interesting, unyoked from the distortions of modern, technological thought.
